thread.title: Sex and violence don't sell: US study
thread.title_full: Sex and violence don't sell: US study

author: news.com.au
title: Sex and violence don't sell: US study
text:
SEX and violence on television, and in movies and advertisements do not help boost product sales and could even end up backfiring, according to a study by the Ohio State University.
THE study, which negates an idea that has dominated the advertising industry for decades, was published by the American Psychological Association, or APA, on its website on Thursday and says although sex and violence increase viewership, this doesn't necessarily translate into more sales.
In fact, violent and sexual content have a negative impact on advertisements or none at all, according to the study. Violent and sexual programs and ads did not increase advertising effectiveness, in fact they decreased it, it further emphasises. Researchers studied the reactions of 8500 participants in around 50 studies to determine the effect of sex and violence on brand memory, brand attitudes and buying intentions. Sexual content also adversely affected viewers' brand memory while the attitude towards the brand is more negative in ads with violence than those that are neutral. Buying intention also decreased when brands were embedded in programs that contained sex or violence.
